_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: All Scf(flox/gfp);Krox20Cre mice (n=20) displayed progressive hair graying with first round occurring homogenously during postnatal days 30-40, converting all black pigmented hairs to white within 9 months
contextSnippet: Invariably, all Scf mice (flox/gfp;Krox20Cre n = 20) displayed progressive hair graying. The first round of hair graying occurred homogenously during postnatal days 30–40 (P30–P40).

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: Krox20 lineage cells showed dynamic localization during HF morphogenesis, detected only in infundibulum and bulge at P0, expanding to entire upper HF at P2, then colonizing matrix beginning at P6-P10
contextSnippet: we found that LacZ+ cells were detected only as a small population of cells located at the infundibulum and bulge of the HF at P0. At P2, LacZ+ cells occupied the entire upper portion of the HF.

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: Scf(flox/gfp);K14Cre mice displayed complete absence of hair pigmentation beginning at birth, lasting throughout their lives (n=8)
contextSnippet: Strikingly, depletion of SCF in keratinocytes resulted in mice displaying a complete absence of hair pigmentation, beginning at birth (Fig. 2 F), and this phenotype was limited to hair pigmentation

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: Scf(flox/gfp);DhhCre mice showed no hair color changes for up to 6 months (n=8), demonstrating hair pigmentation does not depend on SCF expression in Schwann cells
contextSnippet: In mice lacking SCF in Schwann cells (Scf flox/gfp;DhhCre), we did not observe any hair color changes for up to 6 mo (Fig. 2 A). n = 8.

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: Scf(flox/gfp);TyrCreERT2 mice had no phenotype in hair color (n=8), ruling out melanocyte cell-autonomous SCF contributions to hair pigmentation
contextSnippet: mice with SCF depletion in melanocytes (Scf flox/gfp;TyrCreERT2) had no phenotype in hair color (Fig. 2 C) after validation of Cre expression in the hair matrix melanocytes

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: K14-Scf;Scf(flox/gfp);K14Cre mice displayed white hair with dark skin (n=8), unable to rescue hair depigmentation despite ectopic SCF expression under K14 promoter
contextSnippet: Surprisingly, the K14-Scf;Scf flox/gfp;K14Cre mice displayed white hair with dark skin (Fig. 4 A,B), indicating that even though Scf is expressed under a K14 promoter, K14-Scf was unable to rescue

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: DCT immunostaining revealed significant loss of DCT+ differentiated mature melanocytes in Scf(flox/gfp);Krox20Cre mouse HF at P10 (P<0.05) and P11 (P<0.0001)
contextSnippet: DCT immunostaining revealed a significant loss of DCT+ differentiated mature melanocytes in the Scf flox/gfp;Krox20Cre mouse HF at P10 (P < 0.05) and P11 (P < 0.0001)

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: In Scf(flox/gfp);K14Cre mice, KIT+ melanocytes were detected only in lower matrix but completely absent in upper HF matrix, demonstrating SCF loss affects only mature melanocytes
contextSnippet: However, in the skin from Scf flox/gfp;K14Cre mice, KIT+ melanocytes were detected only in the lower matrix but were completely absent in the upper HF matrix

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.

contextSnippet: We observed signs of hair loss (rough coat) starting at starting P40, and they had significant hair loss by P50 (Fig. 7 B). n = 8... Krox20Cre;R26-rtTA;tetO-DTA mice had a complete arrest of new hair generation

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.

contextSnippet: Quantification and statistical analysis of E showing a significant reduction of melanin density in Scf flox/gfp;Krox20Cre graying hair shafts. Melanin density was analyzed by ImageJ.

contextSnippet: The mean total cNF-Skindex score was 40.7 (Table 2). Nine participants had a total cNF-Skindex score that placed them in severity stratum 1 (nonbothersome cNF, 15%), 28 were in stratum 2 (moderately bothersome cNF, 48%) and 22 patients were in stratum 3 (very bothersome cNF, 37%).

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.

contextSnippet: The Cronbach's alpha of the total score and the subdomains were all above 0.90, indicating high internal consistency.

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.
details: Adequate test-retest reliability with Spearman's correlation r=0.88 for total score, r=0.89 for Functioning, r=0.83 for Emotions, and r=0.85 for Symptoms (all p<0.001)
contextSnippet: Adequate test-retest reliability was observed for both the total cNF-Skindex score (Spearman's correlation r = 0.88), the 'Functioning' subdomain (r = 0.89), 'Emotions' subdomain (r = 0.83), and 'Symptoms' subdomain (r = 0.85), with all p-values < 0.001.

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.

contextSnippet: For known-group validity, significant differences in cNF-Skindex scores were observed between participants with ≤ 50 cNF or more than 50 cNF, as well as for participants who had and who had not received a cNF-related intervention

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.

contextSnippet: Regarding convergent validity, the mean Spearman correlation between the total cNF-Skindex score and the items of the EQ-5D-5L was 0.30 (correlations ranging between 0.07 and 0.358, with p-values ranging between 0.005 and 0.606) The Spearman correlation between the total cNF-Skindex score and the EQ-5D-5L VAS was − 0.32 (p-value = 0.012).

The three identified factors ('Functioning', 'Symptoms', and 'Emotions') explained 76.4% of the total variance

contextSnippet: Using Affymetrix Mouse Genome 430 2.0 GeneChip microarrays containing >39,000 transcripts and variants representing ~34,000 mouse genes, a small set of 1446 differential expressed genes (4.2% of total genes) were identified.

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Greater than 98% of cells from CTX, CB, and BS astroglial cultures were GFAP+, while ~30% of ON cells expressed GFAP
contextSnippet: Greater than 98% of the cells from CTX, CB, and BS astroglial cultures were GFAP+...In contrast to astroglial cells from CB, CTX, and BS, ~30% of these cells expressed GFAP

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: >83% of cells from CTX, CB, and BS cultures expressed aquaporin-4, while ~30% of ON cells expressed AQP4
contextSnippet: Similarly, >83% of the cells from these cultures expressed aquaporin-4 (AQP4)...In contrast to astroglial cells from CB, CTX, and BS, ~30% of these cells expressed GFAP, AQP4 or GLAST

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: >83% of cells from CTX, CB, and BS cultures expressed GLAST, while ~30% of ON cells expressed GLAST
contextSnippet: Similarly, >83% of the cells from these cultures expressed aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and the astroglial glutamate transporter GLAST...In contrast to astroglial cells from CB, CTX, and BS, ~30% of these cells expressed GFAP, AQP4 or GLAST

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: ~70% of ON cells expressed NG2 chondroitin sulphate proteoglycan with mutually exclusive expression of NG2 and GFAP
contextSnippet: Interestingly, ~70% of cells expressed the NG2 chondroitin sulphate proteoglycan...It is important to note that there was mutually exclusive expression of NG2 and GFAP in these astroglial cells

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: O4-positive oligodendrocyte lineage cells were rarely detected and no expression found in ON astroglial cell cultures
contextSnippet: In contrast, O4- or APC-positive (oligodendrocyte lineage) cells were rarely detected...we examined the expression of two common OPC markers, O4 and APC, and found no expression of either O4 or APC in these ON astroglial cell cultures

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: APC-positive oligodendrocyte lineage cells were rarely detected and no expression found in ON astroglial cell cultures
contextSnippet: In contrast, O4- or APC-positive (oligodendrocyte lineage) cells were rarely detected...we examined the expression of two common OPC markers, O4 and APC, and found no expression of either O4 or APC in these ON astroglial cell cultures

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: >90% of ON astroglial cells expressed FOXP2 compared to <10% of astroglial cells from CTX, CB and BS
contextSnippet: In addition, FOXP2 immunocytochemistry revealed that >90% positive of ON astroglial cells expressed FOXP2 compared to <10% of the astroglial cells from CTX, CB and BS

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Western blot analysis demonstrated significantly lower levels of neurofibromin expression in CTX astroglial cells than in astroglial cells from other brain regions
contextSnippet: In addition, Western blot analysis also demonstrated significantly lower levels of neurofibromin expression in CTX astroglial cells than in astroglial cells from the other brain regions

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Neurofibromin levels were undetectable in astroglial cells infected with Ad5-Cre compared to Ad5-LacZ
contextSnippet: In all cases, neurofibromin levels were undetectable in astroglial cells infected with Ad5-Cre compared to Ad5-LacZ

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Nf1 inactivation resulted in ≥2-fold increase in proliferation of astroglial cells from CB, BS and ON, but no increase in CTX astroglial cells
contextSnippet: Using [3H]-thymidine incorporation, Nf1 inactivation resulted in ≥2-fold increase in proliferation of astroglial cells from CB, BS and ON. In contrast, no increase in proliferation was observed following Nf1 inactivation in CTX astroglial cells

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Nearly 2-fold increase in GFAP+ cells in BS and significant increase in CB, with 50% increase in NG2 staining in optic nerves, but no effect in CTX
contextSnippet: Whereas there was no effect of Nf1 loss on the number of GFAP+ cells in the CTX, we observed nearly a 2-fold increase in the number of GFAP+ cells in the BS...we detected a 50% increase in NG2 staining in the Nf1GFAP CKO mouse optic nerves

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Increased numbers of Ki-67-immunoreactive cells observed in CB, BS and ON of Nf1GFAP CKO mice, but not in CTX
contextSnippet: Consistent with in vitro proliferation results, we observed increased numbers of Ki-67-immunoreactive cells in CB, BS and ON of Nf1GFAP CKO mice, but not in the CTX

contextSnippet: Cotransfection experiments in HEK 293T cells confirmed complex formation with Merlin for 7 of 10 proteins tested: Angiomotin α-actinin, afadin, ASPP2, Lats1, myosin IIB, Scrib, and ZO-1. Angiomotin interacted with the highest apparent affinity (~100-fold greater than the negative control)

contextSnippet: direct measurements of hippocampal dopamine levels ( Fig. 1B ) and DARPP32 phosphorylation ( Fig. 1D ) reveal a 20% and 61% reduction in CKO mice relative to control mice

details: 61% reduction in DARPP32 phosphorylation compared to control mice

_publicationTitle: Dopamine deficiency underlies learning deficits in neurofibromatosis-1 mice.

contextSnippet: CKO slices display diminished LTP (closed circles, EPSP slope; 128.8+ 7.6%, n=8) in response to high frequency stimulation (HFS) (open circles, EPSP slope; 165.2 + 6.8%, n=8)

_publicationTitle: Dopamine deficiency underlies learning deficits in neurofibromatosis-1 mice.

_publicationTitle: Dopamine deficiency underlies learning deficits in neurofibromatosis-1 mice.

_publicationTitle: Dose-dependent effects of focal fractionated irradiation on secondary malignant neoplasms in Nf1 mutant mice.
details: Survival was reduced compared to WT littermates (p=0.02, logrank test) with deaths occurring after one year of age
contextSnippet: the survival of unirradiated Nf1+/− mice was reduced compared to WT littermates (p=0.02, logrank test) with deaths occurring after one year of age

_publicationTitle: Dose-dependent effects of focal fractionated irradiation on secondary malignant neoplasms in Nf1 mutant mice.
details: Cranial irradiation significantly decreased survival (p=0.05, logrank test) with median post-treatment survival of 503 days versus 596 days in WT mice
contextSnippet: CI significantly decreased the survival of both WT (p=0.002, logrank test) and Nf1+/− (p=0.05, logrank test) mice...median post-treatment survival time was reduced in irradiated Nf1+/− mice compared to irradiated WT mice (503 versus 596 days; p =0.04)

_publicationTitle: Dose-dependent effects of focal fractionated irradiation on secondary malignant neoplasms in Nf1 mutant mice.
details: More likely than WT mice to develop hematologic malignancies (p=0.003, log-rank test) or solid cancers (p=0.05) after irradiation
contextSnippet: irradiated Nf1+/− mutant mice were more likely than irradiated WT mice to develop hematologic malignancies (p=0.003, log-rank test) or solid cancers (p=0.05)

_publicationTitle: Dose-dependent effects of focal fractionated irradiation on secondary malignant neoplasms in Nf1 mutant mice.
details: Highest incidence of myeloid malignancies occurred at 15 Gy dose (0 Gy vs. 15 Gy: p=0.031, 15 Gy vs. 30 Gy: p=0.017)
contextSnippet: highest incidence of myeloid malignancies in Nf1+/− mutant mice that received 15 Gy of CI (0 Gy vs. 15 Gy: p=0.031, 15 Gy vs. 30 Gy: p=0.017, Fisher exact tests)

_publicationTitle: Dose-dependent effects of focal fractionated irradiation on secondary malignant neoplasms in Nf1 mutant mice.
details: Anemia was largely restricted to mice that received 15 Gy of CI, with marked splenic erythroid hyperplasia and persistent bone marrow erythropoiesis
contextSnippet: anemia was largely restricted to Nf1+/− mice that received 15 Gy of CI...marked expansion of the red pulp in the spleen...characterized by a predominance of erythroid cells

_publicationTitle: Dose-dependent effects of focal fractionated irradiation on secondary malignant neoplasms in Nf1 mutant mice.

details: Used to deliver focal, fractionated cranial irradiation with customized beam shaping to replicate clinical treatment
contextSnippet: we developed customized beam shaping to deliver focal, fractionated, CI to mice...Similar to the whole brain irradiation technique used in patients, equally weighted, opposed lateral beams were used

_publicationTitle: Dose-dependent effects of focal fractionated irradiation on secondary malignant neoplasms in Nf1 mutant mice.
details: Obtained complete blood counts from 96 of 121 (80%) mice, revealing anemia largely restricted to Nf1+/- mice receiving 15 Gy
contextSnippet: We obtained complete blood counts (CBCs) from 96 of 121 (80%) mice in the study cohort at death from disease or elective euthanasia and found that anemia was largely restricted to Nf1+/− mice that received 15 Gy of CI

_publicationTitle: Dose-dependent effects of focal fractionated irradiation on secondary malignant neoplasms in Nf1 mutant mice.

contextSnippet: we detected elevated levels of pERK less frequently in primary tumors compared to pAkt and pS6

_publicationTitle: Dose-dependent effects of focal fractionated irradiation on secondary malignant neoplasms in Nf1 mutant mice.

_publicationTitle: A randomized placebo-controlled lovastatin trial for neurobehavioral function in neurofibromatosis I.

contextSnippet: There was a significant differential effect of treatment over time (i.e. significant group x time interaction), favoring the lovastatin group for one primary measure, Letter‐Number Sequencing (P < 0.01; f² = 0.70)

_publicationTitle: A randomized placebo-controlled lovastatin trial for neurobehavioral function in neurofibromatosis I.
details: Significant differential treatment effect favoring lovastatin group (P = 0.02; f² = 0.19), with scores improving from 33.50 to 35.29 in lovastatin group vs declining from 37.67 to 23.50 in placebo group
contextSnippet: There was a significant differential effect of treatment over time...favoring the lovastatin group for...one secondary cognitive measure (HVLT; P = 0.02; f² =0.19)

_publicationTitle: A randomized placebo-controlled lovastatin trial for neurobehavioral function in neurofibromatosis I.
resourceName: Delis–Kaplan Executive Function Scale (D‐KEFS) verbal fluency
details: Differential treatment effect in favor of statin treatment for verbal category fluency (P = 0.02; f² = 0.19), with scores improving from 9.83 to 10.43 in lovastatin group vs declining from 11.33 to 8.50 in placebo group
contextSnippet: There was also a differential effect in favor of statin treatment for verbal category fluency (P = 0.02; f² = 0.19)

_publicationTitle: A randomized placebo-controlled lovastatin trial for neurobehavioral function in neurofibromatosis I.

_publicationTitle: DINs: Deep Interactive Networks for Neurofibroma Segmentation in Neurofibromatosis Type 1 on Whole-Body MRI.
details: Outperforms conventional interactive methods and performs significantly better than automated and interactive CNN-based methods

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
resourceName: Trp53, Nf1, Suz12 triple mutant mice
details: Highest L-[18F]FETrp uptake in pancreas at 5 min (15.8 ± 1.6 ID%/g), increased at 30 min (24.4 ± 15.5 ID%/g), decreased at 60 min (20.5 ± 10.1 ID%/g)
contextSnippet: A biodistribution study in triple mutant mice showed the highest uptake in the pancreas at 5 min post-injection (15.8 ± 1.6 ID%/g). The tracer uptake in the pancreas increased at 30 min (24.4 ± 15.5 ID%/g), followed by a decreased uptake at 60 min (20.5 ± 10.1 ID%/g).

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
resourceName: Trp53, Nf1, Suz12 triple mutant mice
details: Stable bone uptake during 90 min scans (1.49 ± 0.65 ID%/g at 5 min vs. 1.44 ± 0.45 ID%/g at 90 min), indicating stability towards defluorination
contextSnippet: The bone uptake in the triple mutant group remained stable during the 90 min scans (1.49 ± 0.65 ID%/g at 5 min vs. 1.44 ± 0.45 ID%/g at 90 min), further indicating the stability of L-[18F]FETrp towards in vivo defluorination.

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
details: Radiosynthesized with decay-corrected radiochemical yields of 15-28%, specific activity 88-122 GBq/µmol, chemical and enantiomeric purities over 90%, synthesis time ~100 min
contextSnippet: L-[18F]FETrp was radiosynthesized using a one-pot, two-step strategy with decay-corrected radiochemical yields of 15–28%. The specific activity was 88–122 GBq/µmol with chemical and enantiomeric purities over 90%. The entire radiolabeling procedure took approximately 100 min.

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
details: High tumor uptake (SUV 0.64 ± 0.37) with significantly higher tumor-to-brain ratio than FDG (2.0 ± 0.8 vs. 0.7 ± 0.3, p = 0.01)
contextSnippet: Furthermore, the brain had the lowest uptake (SUV 0.31 ± 0.08) and a high tumor uptake (SUV 0.64 ± 0.37)... L-[18F]FETrp showed a significantly higher tumor-to-brain ratio than FDG (2.0 ± 0.8 vs. 0.7 ± 0.3, p = 0.01)

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
details: Metabolically stable with low brain uptake (0.51 ± 0.10 ID%/g at 5 min vs. 1.17 ± 0.15 ID%/g at 90 min) and stable bone uptake indicating no defluorination
contextSnippet: The bone uptake was stable during the 90-min uptake period (1.91 ± 0.52 ID%/g at 5 min post-injection vs. 1.78 ± 0.24 ID%/g at 90 min), indicating the tracer was metabolically stable towards defluorination.

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.

contextSnippet: First, we performed 60-min static scans in wild-type mice and NF1 tumor mice with L-[18F]FETrp and compared the imaging results with the most widely used PET radiotracer, FDG.

details: High TDO2 expression in NF1 tumors, low expression in brain and muscle, associated with high tumor uptake of L-[18F]FETrp
contextSnippet: The IHC results showed that the NF1 tumors had high IDO, TDO2, and AHR expressions, which is associated with a high tumor uptake of L-[18F]FETrp in PET imaging. However, both brain and muscle showed low IDO and TDO2 expressions

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
resourceName: AHR antibody mouse monoclonal (1:50, Santa Cruz, Dallas, TX, USA)
details: High AHR expression in NF1 tumors and muscle, associated with tumor uptake patterns of L-[18F]FETrp
contextSnippet: The IHC results showed that the NF1 tumors had high IDO, TDO2, and AHR expressions, which is associated with a high tumor uptake of L-[18F]FETrp in PET imaging... while the AHR expression in the muscle was high.

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Quadriceps muscle showed significantly different AF spectra means (p < 0.05 between ~450 and 720 nm) and DR spectra with more pronounced absorption feature between 500-600 nm compared to controls
contextSnippet: Normalized AF spectra from B6 and NF1 quadricep muscles showed significantly different means (p < 0.05 between ~450 and 720 nm). NF1 DR spectra showed a more pronounced absorption feature between 500 and 600 nm

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Strong quadriceps separability from controls demonstrated by QDC classifier AUCs of 0.99 for AF and 0.97 for DR spectroscopy
contextSnippet: Both AF and DR demonstrated strong quadriceps separability as indicated by distinct PC score clustering and QDC classifier AUC's of 0.99 and 0.97, respectively

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Quadriceps muscle histology showed endomysial fibrosis and intramyocellular lipid accumulation by H&E and Oil Red O staining
contextSnippet: NF1 muscle histology showed endomysial fibrosis and intramyocellular lipid by H&E and Oil Red O staining, respectively, consistent with prior findings

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Cardiac muscle showed no spectral differences from controls (p > 0.05) with poor QDC classification performance (ROC-AUCs of 0.67 AF, 0.63 DR)
contextSnippet: B6 and NF1 cardiac muscle showed similar spectral shapes and the same mean normalized intensity across almost all wavelengths for both AF and DR (p > 0.05). This similarity resulted in overlapping PC score clusters and poor QDC classification performance with ROC-AUCs of 0.67 and 0.63

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Strong AF separability from controls at 3 weeks (AUC = 0.98) and 10 weeks (AUC = 0.87), with modest DR separability (AUC = 0.73 at 3 weeks, 0.77 at 10 weeks)
contextSnippet: B10WT and B10 mdx mice were compared at 3 weeks, with strong AF separability, AUC = 0.98 and with more modest DR separability, AUC = 0.73. Finally, B10WT and B10 mdx mice were compared at 10 weeks, with similar results to that of 3 weeks, with stronger separability using AF, AUC = 0.87 and modest separability using DR, AUC = 0.77

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: 10-week-old quadriceps muscle showed centralized nuclei and degenerating/regenerating muscle fibers by H&E staining, while 3-week-old muscle showed no pathological features
contextSnippet: Histology of B10 mdx mouse quadricep muscle found features of dystrophy consistent with the literature. This included centralized nuclei and degenerating/regenerating muscle fibers as seen using H&E histological staining. 3-week-old B10 mdx mouse muscle showed no pathological features

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Strong temporal separability between 3 and 10 weeks using AF spectroscopy (AUC = 0.96) and modest separability using DR (AUC = 0.77)
contextSnippet: B10 mdx at 3 and 10 weeks showed differences in AF spectral features resulting in strong classifier performance, AUC = 0.96, whereas DR spectra were only modestly separable, AUC = 0.77

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Cardiac muscle was well separable from all skeletal muscles in both AF and DR analyses (AUC = 1 for both), while skeletal muscles were less separable with AUCs ranging between 0.79 and 0.99
contextSnippet: The cardiac muscle was well separable from all skeletal muscles in both AF and DR analyses (AUC = 1 for AF and DR, respectively), whereas skeletal muscles (Quad, Gastr, and TA) were less separable with AUCs ranging between 0.79 and 0.99

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Used for statistical analysis and PCA-based spectral analysis with QDC classification achieving AUCs ranging from 0.58 to 0.99 across different muscle comparisons
contextSnippet: Statistical analysis of normalized spectra was applied to generate 95% confidence intervals. To enhance muscle group separability and resulting classification accuracy, spectra were dimensionally reduced using PCA

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: 80% of Nf1 (-/-) fibroblast cell strains showed increased growth over wild-type cultures in 5-day growth assays
contextSnippet: This result has been replicated in 5-day growth assays of fibroblasts from over 100 Nf1 mouse embryos: 80% of Nf1 (−/−) cell strains showed increased growth over wild-type cultures.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Fibroblasts from Nf1 (-/-) embryos contained no detectable neurofibromin by Western blot analysis
contextSnippet: Western blot analysis confirmed that fibroblasts from Nf1 (−/−) embryos contained no detectable neurofibromin, while heterozygous cells showed a reduction as compared to wild-type cells

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Nf1 (-/-) cultures showed 1% as many perineurium-surrounded fascicles as wild-type sections at 30 days in vitro
contextSnippet: At 30 days in vitro, Nf1 (−/−) cultures showed 1% as many as those from wild-type sections.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.

contextSnippet: Cultures containing fibroblasts without neurofibromin showed 17.7% and 23.8% as many fascicles as those with wild-type fascicles.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Nf1 (+/-) fibroblasts contained 60% as many fascicles as wild-type cultures at 30 days in vitro
contextSnippet: Cultures with Nf1 (+/−) fibroblasts contained 60% as many fascicles as wild-type cultures.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.

contextSnippet: Western blot analysis confirmed that fibroblasts from Nf1 (−/−) embryos contained no detectable neurofibromin, while heterozygous cells showed a reduction as compared to wild-type cells

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Lack of neurofibromin did not appear to cause changes in neuronal differentiation in response to nerve growth factor under culture conditions
contextSnippet: Lack of neurofibromin did not by itself appear to cause changes in neuron-Schwann cell adhesion or in neuronal differentiation in response to nerve growth factor under these culture conditions

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.

contextSnippet: Cells with these characteristics were identified in cultures containing both Nf1 (−/−) and wild-type fibroblasts, suggesting that even fibroblasts without neurofibromin are capable of responding to cues

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.

contextSnippet: By Day 6 (passage 0), sphere formation was significantly inhibited in cells treated with MLN8237 in comparison to the vehicle alone treated cells (166 to 29 spheres in the DMSO and MLN8237 treated cells, respectively. p<0.05)

contextSnippet: reduced TPX2 protein abundance by approximately 40%. However, the reduced expression of TPX2 did not alter the IC-50 for MLN8237 or VX680

contextSnippet: SC lineage cells enriched with MES-SCP/NC–like cells isolated from NPE-mut sciatic nerve tumors were highly tumorigenic when engrafted in immunocompromised mice. They were able to propagate tumors that resembled aggressive MPNST when serially transplanted

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Knockdown of ALDH1A1 blocked MPNST tumor cell proliferation
contextSnippet: Similarly, knockdown of an EMT/stemness regulator ALDH1A1 also blocked MPNST tumor cell proliferation

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Used in xenograft assays where ZEB1 shRNA knockdown impeded tumor growth compared to control

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.

contextSnippet: we performed single-cell transcriptome profiling [single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq)] using the Drop-seq platform

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.

contextSnippet: we identified advanced tumor-specific mesenchymal neural crest–like tumor cells as the stem cell–like starting cell population; these cells followed a differentiation path toward tumor neural crest–like cells, mesenchymal SCPs, and subsequently to more committed SC lineage populations

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Determined tumorigenesis trajectory initiated in mature SCs, proceeded through neoplastic SC subpopulation, reached bifurcation point with mesenchymal traits, and ended in MES-NC–like tumor subclusters
contextSnippet: The tumorigenesis trajectory initiated in mature SCs, proceeded through a neoplastic SC subpopulation, reached a bifurcation point enriched with tumor-like SCPs with mesenchymal traits, and ended in the MES-NC–like tumor subclusters

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Predicted most differentiated cell cluster as myelinating SC cluster and most stem cell–like population as tumor cell cluster with neural crest/mesenchymal phenotype, consistent with dedifferentiation path
contextSnippet: Consistent with a dedifferentiation path, the most differentiated cell cluster is the myelinating SC cluster, whereas the most stem cell–like population is the tumor cell cluster with neural crest/mesenchymal phenotype

contextSnippet: upon loss of NF1 there is a decrease in oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) and Myelination Signaling Pathway. We see increases in Mitochondrial dysfunction and Glycolysis

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.

details: Shows clear genetic separation from WMS-WT herd and reveals distinct subpopulations within the herd when analyzed independently

_publicationTitle: The draft genome of the Wisconsin Miniature SwineTM, a valuable biomedical research tool.
details: Generated draft assembly consisting of 1,215 contigs with mean coverage of 17X from 48 Gb ONT sequencing data
contextSnippet: Using the Flye assembler, we generated a draft WMS TM assembly consisting of 1,215 contigs exhibiting a mean coverage of 17X.

_publicationTitle: The draft genome of the Wisconsin Miniature SwineTM, a valuable biomedical research tool.
details: Achieved BUSCO score of 98.2% ([S:97.9%, D:0.3%], F:1.0%, M:0.8%) for WMS assembly, surpassing existing S. scrofa reference genomes
contextSnippet: The WMS TM draft assembly achieved a BUSCO score of 98.2% ([S:97.9%, D:0.3%], F:1.0%, M:0.8%), indicating that we have a highly complete assembly... The BUSCO assessment of the assembly generated here surpasses the BUSCO scores for existing S. scrofa reference genomes (Sscrofa11.1 = 93.8% and USMARCv1.0 = 93.1%)

_publicationTitle: The draft genome of the Wisconsin Miniature SwineTM, a valuable biomedical research tool.
details: Resulted in 97.76% match with Sscrofa11.1 annotations with alignment coverage and sequence identity ≥50%, identifying 19,853 matches (96.4%) out of 20,306 annotations
contextSnippet: When applied to WMS TM , the lift-over annotation resulted in a 97.76% match with Sscrofa11.1 annotations with an alignment coverage and sequence identity ≥50%. The gene features in the S. scrofa genome used in our analysis included 20,306 annotations, of which we identified 19,853 matches (96.4%).

_publicationTitle: Quantitative MRI of dorsal root ganglion alterations in neurofibromatosis type 1 patients with or without pain.
details: Used for voxel-wise DRG segmentation performed manually by two independent, blinded raters, achieving very good inter-rater intraclass correlation coefficient for DRG volume (0.94) and PD (0.98) and good correlation for T2 (0.70)
contextSnippet: The inter-rater intraclass correlation coefficient (two-way, agreement) was 0.94 (95% confidence interval 0.87–0.97) for DRG volume, 0.70 (0.60–0.78) for DRG T2, and 0.98 (0.94–0.99) for DRG PD.

_publicationTitle: Quantitative MRI of dorsal root ganglion alterations in neurofibromatosis type 1 patients with or without pain.
details: Used for receiver operating characteristic analysis showing DRG PD parameter achieved AUC = 0.84 for discriminating between pain and non-pain phenotype in NF1 patients, with optimal threshold of 0.918 a.u. giving sensitivity of 0.75 and specificity of 0.92
contextSnippet: For discriminating between pain and non-pain phenotype in NF1 patients, the DRG PD parameter (AUC = 0.84; Fig. 4) was superior to DRG volume (AUC = 0.72) and DRG T2 (AUC = 0.71)

_publicationTitle: Quantitative MRI of dorsal root ganglion alterations in neurofibromatosis type 1 patients with or without pain.
details: Used for statistical analysis demonstrating significant differences in DRG measurements between NF1 patients and controls, including 176.3% increase in DRG volume (p < 0.001), 22.9% increase in T2 relaxation time (p = 0.007), and 8.4% increase in PD (p = 0.007)
contextSnippet: DRG from patients with NF1 (n = 20) showed a significant increase in volume (+176.3%; median 1,736.5 versus 628.4 mm³, p < 0.001), T2 relaxation time (+22.9%; median 118.2 versus 96.2 ms, p = 0.007), and PD (+8.4%; median 0.903 versus 0.833 a.u., p = 0.007)

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromatosis type 1-dependent alterations in mouse microglia function are not cell-intrinsic.

contextSnippet: male Nf1± microglia had a ramification index (4.8 ± 0.1; n = 106 cells/4 mice) that was smaller than that observed for male WT microglia (6.2 ± 0.2; n = 53 cells/2 mice; p < 0.0001)

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromatosis type 1-dependent alterations in mouse microglia function are not cell-intrinsic.

_publicationTitle: Exome sequencing on malignant meningiomas identified mutations in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and meningioma 1 (MN1) genes.
details: Generated on average 45 million paired-end 90 bp reads per sample with mean depth coverage of 54X and 93.4% of bases covered by at least 10X
contextSnippet: After removing low-quality reads, we obtained on average 45 million paired-end 90 bp reads per sample. Alignment statistics showed mean depth coverage of 54X, and 93.4% of bases were covered by at least 10X.

_publicationTitle: Exome sequencing on malignant meningiomas identified mutations in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and meningioma 1 (MN1) genes.
details: Successfully identified and prioritized on average 170 novel protein-altering variants per sample from ~62,000 unique variants
contextSnippet: We applied the 'variants reduction' pipeline implemented in the wANNOVAR server and identified a small subset of candidate variants and genes...we prioritized on average 170 novel protein-altering variants per sample

_publicationTitle: Exome sequencing on malignant meningiomas identified mutations in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and meningioma 1 (MN1) genes.
details: Achieved higher depth coverage with on average 455X read depth and 100% of targeted regions covered
contextSnippet: Since the targeted region sequencing captures a smaller region compared to WGS or WES, we were able to obtain sequencing data with higher depth coverage on the targeted regions: on average, the read depth is 455X and 100% of targeted regions are covered.

_publicationTitle: Exome sequencing on malignant meningiomas identified mutations in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and meningioma 1 (MN1) genes.
details: Used to implement consensus variant calling approach with GATK and SAMtools to ensure reliability of variant calls
contextSnippet: we did a comparative approach by using two independent variant calling tools [GATK and SAMtools, implemented by SeqMule pipeline] and by using the consensus variants from both variant calling tools as candidate variants

_publicationTitle: RABL6A Regulates Schwann Cell Senescence in an RB1-Dependent Manner.

contextSnippet: Loss of RABL6A led to a dramatic reduction in phosphorylated RB1-S807/811 as well as stark upregulation of p16 expression...significant upregulation of SA-βgal staining

_publicationTitle: RABL6A Regulates Schwann Cell Senescence in an RB1-Dependent Manner.

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.

contextSnippet: S462-TY MPNST cells show limited sensitivity to MEK inhibition. At 24 hours, 125 µmol/L selumetinib alone results in ∼65% of the cells showing an accumulation in the S-phase

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.

contextSnippet: Treatment of S462-TY cells with selumetinib alone for 24 hours resulted in significant (P < 0.0001) feedback activation of the RAS pathway as detected by RAS–GTP levels

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.

contextSnippet: Each line was injected into the flanks of four mice and monitored for signs of tumor formation for 16 weeks. Tumor formation was never observed for the NF1-proficient cell lines. In contrast, all NF1-deficient lines showed the ability to form tumors upon xenograft, with 50% penetrance

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
resourceName: NOD-Rag1 null IL2rg null, NOD rag gamma, NOD-RG (NRG) mice (RRID: JAX:007799)

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
resourceName: NOD-Rag1 null IL2rg null, NOD rag gamma, NOD-RG (NRG) mice (RRID: JAX:007799)
details: Digoxin + selumetinib combination showed dramatic survival improvement with long-term survivors and some animals having no detectable tumors at study conclusion
contextSnippet: Not only did the combination significantly outperform either of the single agents, but we also observed long-term survivors at the conclusion of the study. Some animals had no detectable tumors at the conclusion of the study

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Vehicle-treated animals had median survival of 18 days, while single-agent treatments extended survival: rigosertib (22 days), LB100 (24 days), digoxin (27 days), DMAPT (27.5 days), selumetinib (24 days)
contextSnippet: Vehicle-treated animals had a median survival of 18 days, whereas the cohorts treated with rigosertib (22 days), LB100 (24 days), digoxin (27 days), DMAPT (27.5 days), and selumetinib (24 days) showed increased survival

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Combination therapies showed dramatic increases in median survival: rigosertib + selumetinib (22 to 47 days) and digoxin + selumetinib (27 to 47.5 days), P < 0.001
contextSnippet: The rigosertib + selumetinib and digoxin + selumetinib combinations each showed dramatic increases in median survival when compared with their single-agent results (22 to 47 days and 27 to 47.5 days, respectively, P < 0.001)

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: All single agents and combinations were well tolerated with no signs of toxicity including therapy-related lethargy or gastrointestinal issues
contextSnippet: These compounds were well tolerated, with none of the single agents or combinations tested in this model eliciting signs of toxicity in the mice, including therapy-related lethargy or gastrointestinal issues

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Selumetinib + digoxin combination showed increase in survival and reduction in tumor growth, though not as robust as in GEMM or cell line xenograft
contextSnippet: We also tested the selumetinib + digoxin combination in an MPNST PDX grown in NRG mice. In the PDX, an increase in survival and reduction in tumor growth was also observed, although it was not as robust as the response seen in the GEMM or MPNST cell line xenograft

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Selumetinib + rigosertib combination showed superior tumor growth control compared to monotherapy with corresponding increase in overall survival, and significantly better response than selumetinib + digoxin combination
contextSnippet: when the selumetinib + rigosertib combination was tested in the MPNST PDX mentioned, control of tumor growth was superior to either monotherapy, and there was a corresponding increase in overall survival. The response of this combination in the PDX model was significantly better than the selumetinib + digoxin combination

_publicationTitle: Novel age-dependent targets in vestibular schwannomas.
details: Successfully identified 21 significantly differentially expressed genes between early-onset and late-onset vestibular schwannomas with fold change >1.5 and p value <0.01
contextSnippet: Twenty one significantly differentially expressed genes are identified by fold change >1.5 and p value <0.01: ANLN, NAV3, ZNF718, PSCD3, C180rf54, C10rf79, XPO1, GMNN, WHSC1, EPHA2, SNF1LK2, NGFRAP1L1, ELL2, SYTL3, KCNK17, IGLV1-44, PID1, RGN, PTPN1, ZNF331, and RNF19A

_publicationTitle: Novel age-dependent targets in vestibular schwannomas.
resourceName: DNA Engine Opticon 2 Continuous Fluorescence Detection System
details: Validated differential expression of 4 key genes with high statistical significance: SNF1LK2 (p=2×10⁻⁷), NGFRAP1L1/BEX5 (p=0.0002), GMNN (p=0.0009), and EPHA2 (p=9×10⁻⁶), all p<0.005
contextSnippet: RT-PCR confirmed the results for these genes and t test for all genes were significant at p value <0.005 (SNF1LK2 p value 2 × 10⁻⁷, NGFRAP1L1 (BEX5) p value 0.0002, GMNN p value 0.0009, and EPHA2 p value 9 × 10⁻⁶)

_publicationTitle: Novel age-dependent targets in vestibular schwannomas.
details: Generated volcano scatter plot analysis showing statistically significant differential gene expression between early and late onset vestibular schwannomas using fold change and t-test criteria
contextSnippet: The results were summarized in a volcano scatter plot that summarizes both fold change and t test criteria. The negative log 10-transformed p values from the gene-specific t test was plotted against the log 2 fold change between early and late onset

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.
details: Used for molecular dynamics simulations to generate training sets with 9 inhibitor-free and 9 inhibitor-bound complexes, enabling machine learning classification of TRAP1 allosteric states
contextSnippet: ML models were built to ensure learning of inhibitor-bound patterns from the allosteric ligands expected to have the biggest detectable impact on TRAP1 local unperturbed dynamics.

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.
details: Used for analysis of MD trajectories to extract local features including residue-level solvation, contacts, and distances from flexible regions of TRAP1 monomers
contextSnippet: We focused on residue-level solvation, contacts, and distances obtained from four inherently flexible regions of the buckled and straight monomers

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.
details: Machine learning models achieved 66.7-94.9% average accuracy in cross-validation, with GDF-SVM showing highest performance (94.9% accuracy, 0.95 TPR, 0.95 TNR)
contextSnippet: The average accuracy in each validation fold varies between 66.7 and 94.9%, with the discriminative models outperforming the generative ones

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.

contextSnippet: 68–69% of inhibitor-free trajectories can be genuinely recovered as TN. For NB models, the loss in specificity is lower, in the range of 2–23%

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.

contextSnippet: showing a significant r² value of 0.71 for the KNB model... ML-based classification of inhibitors from MD simulations outperform docking-based models

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.

details: Showed impaired spatial learning in Morris water maze, utilizing exclusively non-spatial search strategy with no preference for target quadrant
contextSnippet: Nf1 9a−/9a− mice utilized an exclusively non-spatial search strategy and showed no preference for the target quadrant

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: 36 ± 7% reduction in total Nf1 mRNA and 39 ± 2% reduction in total neurofibromin protein in hippocampus
contextSnippet: total Nf1 mRNA was reduced by 36 ± 7% (n = 9), with concomitant reduction of total neurofibromin protein (a reduction of 39 ± 2% in the hippocampus, n = 11)

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Showed significant deficit in theta burst stimulation-induced LTP, but normal LTP when induced using high-frequency stimulation protocol
contextSnippet: Nf1 9a−/9a− mice showed a significant deficit in TBS-induced LTP. Consistent with the sensitivity of TBS-induced LTP to changes in GABAergic inhibition, LTP was normal when induced using a high-frequency stimulation (HFS) protocol

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Showed increased inhibitory postsynaptic potential amplitude at higher stimulus levels and reduced paired-pulse ratio, suggesting enhanced GABA release
contextSnippet: inhibitory postsynaptic potential amplitude was bigger at higher stimulus levels in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice, whereas paired-pulse ratio was reduced, suggesting a change in presynaptic GABA release

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: PV neurons showed 7 mV hyperpolarizing shift in I_h half-activation potential (-88.4 ± 1.9 mV vs -81.2 ± 2.0 mV in WT)
contextSnippet: Fits of the activation curve with a Boltzmann function yielded a hyperpolarizing shift of 7 mV in the half-activation potential (V1/2) in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice (-88.4 ± 1.9 mV, n = 10) compared with their WT littermates (-81.2 ± 2.0 mV, n = 7, P < 0.01)

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: PV neurons had hyperpolarized resting membrane potential (-64.1 ± 0.7 mV vs -60.6 ± 0.7 mV) and higher input resistance (279 ± 19 MΩ vs 235 ± 14 MΩ)
contextSnippet: PV neurons of Nf1 9a−/9a− mice had a significantly hyperpolarized resting membrane potential (-64.1 ± 0.7 mV, n = 17 vs -60.6 ± 0.7 mV, n = 12; P < 0.005) and a higher input resistance (279 ± 19 MΩ, n = 15 vs 235 ± 14 MΩ, n = 16, P < 0.05)

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: At 50 μM, increased I_h magnitude and caused significant depolarizing shift in activation, fully normalizing V1/2 to -80.9 ± 2.0 mV in Nf1 PV neurons
contextSnippet: LTG increased the magnitude of Ih in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice and caused a significant depolarizing shift in Ih activation in Nf1 9a−/9a− PV neurons, which was fully normalized compared with recordings from WT mice. The V1/2 in the presence of LTG was −80.9 ± 2.0 mV (n = 9)

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Caused reduction of action potential firing rates in Nf1 PV neurons, with effect blocked by prior HCN antagonist ZD7288 application
contextSnippet: bath application of LTG caused a reduction of action potential firing rates in response to depolarizing current injections in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice. To determine whether the effect of LTG on membrane excitability was directly mediated via Ih, the HCN antagonist ZD7288 was applied before application of LTG. In this condition, the effect of LTG on membrane excitability was fully blocked

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Restored LTP in Nf1 mice to the level of WT mice at Schaffer collateral-CA1 synapses
contextSnippet: LTG restored LTP in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice to the level of WT mice, whereas the LTP deficit remained evident in vehicle-treated slices from Nf1 9a−/9a− mice

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: At 25 mg/kg i.p., restored spatial learning capacity in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice, showing clear preference for target quadrant in Morris water maze
contextSnippet: LTG treatment restored the learning capacity of Nf1 9a−/9a− mice, without altering the performance of their WT littermates. Furthermore, and consistent with a prominent influence of HCN channel function in the pathophysiology of the Nf1+/− mouse model, Nf1+/− mice treated with LTG also showed a clear preference for the target quadrant

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Successfully detected spatial learning impairments in both Nf1 9a−/9a− and Nf1+/− mice, with deficits rescued by lamotrigine treatment
contextSnippet: Nf1 9a−/9a− mice were tested in the Morris water maze task previously demonstrated to be impaired in Nf1+/− mice. Indeed, Nf1 9a−/9a− mice utilized an exclusively non-spatial search strategy and showed no preference for the target quadrant

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Detected motor coordination deficits in Nf1+/− mice that were completely rescued by lamotrigine treatment
contextSnippet: Nf1+/− mice showed impaired learning on the accelerating rotarod, a motor learning paradigm that does not depend on hippocampal function. Indeed, LTG treatment completely rescued the motor coordination deficit in Nf1+/− mice

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Showed dramatic increase in Ras-ERK pathway with phosphorylated ERK1 at 212% of WT and ERK2 at 246% of WT in hippocampus
contextSnippet: H-RasG12V mice showed a dramatic increase of the Ras-ERK pathway, as measured by the relative level of phosphorylated ERK1 (212% of WT, P < 0.01) and ERK2 (246% of WT, P < 0.001) in the hippocampus

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Despite marked ERK activation, showed no alterations in I_h current-voltage relationship, voltage dependence, or PV neuron excitability compared to WT
contextSnippet: in contrast to Nf1 mutant mice, the current–voltage relationship and voltage dependence of Ih in PV neurons were similar between H-RasG12V and WT littermates. Furthermore, the slope of activation and the Ih kinetics remained intact. Consistent with the absence of any detectable changes in Ih, neither the resting membrane potential nor the input resistance was altered in H-RasG12V PV neurons

However, the 2 (CON/NF1) × 3 (ML/MM/MR) × 2 (1-/2-back) ANOVA using task-specific (adjusted) theta phase coherence showed no significant main effects or interactions involving the factor 'group'

_publicationTitle: Antisense oligonucleotides targeting exon 11 are able to partially rescue the NF2-related schwannomatosis phenotype

_publicationTitle: Antisense oligonucleotides targeting exon 11 are able to partially rescue the NF2-related schwannomatosis phenotype

_publicationTitle: Antisense oligonucleotides targeting exon 11 are able to partially rescue the NF2-related schwannomatosis phenotype

contextSnippet: Patient_ES11_1 showed a statistically significant depletion of proliferation when treated with PMOs (65.6%; p < 0.05), while patient_ES11_2 showed a less pronounced decrease (25.1%)

_publicationTitle: Antisense oligonucleotides targeting exon 11 are able to partially rescue the NF2-related schwannomatosis phenotype
resourceName: Click-iT EdU Alexa Fluor 488 Flow Cytometry Assay Kit

_publicationTitle: Antisense oligonucleotides targeting exon 11 are able to partially rescue the NF2-related schwannomatosis phenotype

_publicationTitle: Antisense oligonucleotides targeting exon 11 are able to partially rescue the NF2-related schwannomatosis phenotype

_publicationTitle: Antisense oligonucleotides targeting exon 11 are able to partially rescue the NF2-related schwannomatosis phenotype

_publicationTitle: Exhaustive non-synonymous variants functionality prediction enables high resolution characterization of the neurofibromin architecture.
details: Used for variant annotation including genetic effect prediction and variant type classification in the analysis of 22,323 NF1 variants
contextSnippet: Variants were annotated with their predicted genetic effect, the rate of pathogenic variants was calculated for each genetic effect and an odds ratio was calculated in order to rank them according to their association with pathogenicity.

_publicationTitle: Exhaustive non-synonymous variants functionality prediction enables high resolution characterization of the neurofibromin architecture.
details: Provided functional prediction scores used as input features for the NF1-specific machine learning model, which achieved AUC of 0.946 for nonsynonymous variants and 0.962 including splice variants
contextSnippet: In order to train our own prediction model, we used as input the scores provided by each prediction tool, together with various other annotations... The model demonstrated a significantly higher AUC value than the tool with the highest AUC (0.946; P < 0.05).

_publicationTitle: Exhaustive non-synonymous variants functionality prediction enables high resolution characterization of the neurofibromin architecture.
details: Used to implement stacked ensemble machine learning algorithms that achieved superior performance with AUC of 0.946 for nonsynonymous variants, significantly outperforming existing tools
contextSnippet: The final model was based on a stacked ensemble of four different machine learning algorithms... The model demonstrated a significantly higher AUC value than the tool with the highest AUC (0.946; P < 0.05).

_publicationTitle: Exhaustive non-synonymous variants functionality prediction enables high resolution characterization of the neurofibromin architecture.

contextSnippet: In order to allow researchers and clinicians to evaluate NF1 variants of interest, we generated a webserver that includes the entire set of NF1 nonsynonymous and splice site variants with various annotations, including our model's final score

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.
details: High dose abdominal irradiation (15 and 30 Gy) reduced overall survival in a dose-dependent manner (log-rank test p<0.0001), with median survivals of 469 and 410 days respectively compared to 583 days for unirradiated controls
contextSnippet: radiation-exposure reduced the overall survival of Nf1+/− mice in a dose-dependent manner (log-rank test p<0.0001, Figure 1B) at higher dose levels (15 and 30 Gy). The median survivals of Nf1+/− mice receiving 0, 3, 15, and 30 Gy were 583, 652, 469 and 410 days, respectively.

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.
details: Tumor incidence increased with increasing radiation dose (p < 0.0001 by χ2 analysis), demonstrating enhanced radiation-induced tumorigenesis compared to wildtype mice
contextSnippet: Tumors were more common in Nf1+/− mice than WT mice, and for Nf1+/− mice tumor incidence increased with increasing radiation dose (p < 0.0001 by χ2 analysis, Figure 2)

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.
details: Sarcomas were significantly more common in irradiated Nf1+/- mice than irradiated wildtype mice (p = 0.0175, log-rank)
contextSnippet: sarcomas are well recognized SMNs after high-dose radiation therapy (21–23), and were significantly more common in irradiated Nf1+/− mice than irradiated WT mice (p = 0.0175, log-rank)

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.
details: Solid tumor free survival and hematologic disease free survival were both reduced in a dose-dependent manner (log rank test, p<0.0001 for solid tumor free survival and p=0.0001 for hematologic disease free survival)
contextSnippet: solid tumor free survival and hematologic disease free survival were both reduced in a dose-dependent manner in Nf1+/− mice but not WT mice (Figure 3, log rank test, p<0.0001 for solid tumor free survival in Nf1+/− mice and p=0.0001 for hematologic disease free survival in Nf1+/− mice)

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.
details: Significantly increased mean terminal splenic weight compared to wildtype mice in unirradiated controls
contextSnippet: found significantly increased mean terminal splenic weight in unirradiated Nf1+/− mice as compared to WT mice (Supplementary Figure 2A)

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.
details: Loss of heterozygosity was a common event in tumors, with LOH of Nf1 accompanied by LOH of at least one microsatellite in 87% of all tumors
contextSnippet: Microsatellite and SNP sequencing analysis revealed that loss of heterozygosity was a common event in tumors isolated from Nf1+/− mutant mice (Figure 5), and the frequency of LOH at rs13481119 was similar across the three major classes of solid malignancies... LOH of Nf1 was accompanied by LOH of at least one of the microsatellites in 87% percent of all tumors

_publicationTitle: Influences of RASopathies on Neuroanatomical Variation in Children.

_publicationTitle: Influences of RASopathies on Neuroanatomical Variation in Children.

_publicationTitle: Influences of RASopathies on Neuroanatomical Variation in Children.

contextSnippet: we found significant group differences after FDR correction in the left and right putamen ( p =0.003, p =0.002), left and right accumbens ( p =0.003, p= 1.3e −4 ), left and right caudate ( p =0.004, p =0.005), and left pallidum ( p= 0.022)

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Successfully performed Tumor-Normal matching analysis on FASTQ files from whole exome sequencing data
contextSnippet: The FASTQ files were loaded into the Varsome Clinical software v.12.3.2 to perform Tumor–Normal matching.

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Identified 67 CNVs in primary tumor, 233 CNVs in lung metastasis, and 243 CNVs in skin metastasis
contextSnippet: Finally, we used Varsome Clinical software (v12.3.2) to identify CNVs. The primary tumor exhibits a total of 67 CNVs, dissimilar metastases, which show 233 and 243 CNVs, respectively.

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Successfully performed CNV calling and revealed greater genomic instability in metastases with log2 ratio values of about 3 and -3
contextSnippet: Finally, we performed the calling of CNVs using the CNVkit...the metastases show a more pronounced presence of amplifications and deletions, suggesting greater genomic instability...with log2 ratio values of about 3 and −3

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Kaplan-Meier analysis identified 6 genes (RBMX, PNPLA6, C1S, LAMB3, SMC1A, PLOD2) associated with lower and significant patient survival in sarcoma samples
contextSnippet: Using The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) database related to sarcoma samples (SARC), accessible via the GEPIA portal...we observed that a change in expression of RBMX, PNPLA6, C1S, LAMB3, SMC1A and PLOD2 was associated with lower and significant patient survival

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Analysis of metastatic samples identified 4 genes (AGAP2, VSIG8, RBMX, PRSS2) associated with reduced overall survival in lung and skin cancer datasets
contextSnippet: For the metastatic samples, we chose to perform Kaplan–Meier analysis on common genes...Out of 14 common genes, only expression changes in AGAP2, VSIG8, RBMX and PRSS2 were associated with reduced overall survival

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Successfully performed pathway analysis identifying statistically significant GO terms, KEGG pathways, and Reactome pathways associated with cell motility, division, signaling and metabolism for primary tumor
contextSnippet: To define a biological significance of the candidate genes, we performed a pathway analysis using the information available in the Gene Ontology (GO), Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway and Reactome databases, obtaining statistically significant results only for the primary tumor gene list.

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).
details: Overall patient-reported distress rating was 3.4 (SD = 3.5, range = 0–10), below the validated clinical cutoff of 4
contextSnippet: The overall patient-reported distress rating was 3.4 (SD = 3.5, range = 0–10). The overall mean distress ratings for each of the age groups was reported below the validated clinical cutoff of 4.

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).
details: Poor caregiver/patient concordance with only 13-17 year olds showing significant but modest correlation (r = 0.41, p < 0.05)
contextSnippet: Caregiver/patient and provider/patient concordance were both quite poor. Only one age group (13–17 year olds) exhibited a significant, but modest, correlation in reported distress levels between the caregivers and their child (r = 0.41, p < 0.05).

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).
details: 44% of caregivers designated a different distress category than was reported by their child
contextSnippet: When classified as 'low distress' (DT rating of 0–3), 'moderate distress' (DT Rating of 4–6), and 'high distress' (DT rating of 7–10), 44% of caregivers designated a different distress category than was reported by their child.

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).
resourceName: Distress Thermometer Acceptability and Feasibility Scales
details: 65.8% of patients, 79% of caregivers, and 87.5% of medical providers reported the DT was very easy to complete
contextSnippet: Nearly 80% of caregivers, 87.5% of medical providers and 65.8% of patients reported that the DT was very easy to complete, with another 12.8%, 11.3% and 30.4%, respectively, reporting that it was somewhat easy.

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).

contextSnippet: When asked if they were bothered by having to complete it, 97.4% of caregivers, 96.3% of medical providers and 92.4% of patients reported that it 'didn't bother me at all'

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).

contextSnippet: Among the children (ages 7–17), one child (1.3%) endorsed wanting to kill him/herself, and another 6.3% reported that they had thoughts about killing themselves... The one person who wanted to kill him/herself had the highest CDI score and had a safety evaluation

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).

contextSnippet: The average performance status score was 92.5 for children under 18... Performance status scores were significantly correlated to DT scores for medical provider ratings and patient ratings, for patients under 18 (r = −.27, p < .05 for patient rating)

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).

contextSnippet: Caregiver distress was identified on the BSI with 12.5% meeting criteria for a 'case' (t-score greater or equal to 63) on somatization, 11.3% for anxiety, and 3.8% for depression and 8.8% for the Global Severity Index.

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).

contextSnippet: Our findings suggest that the DT and problem checklist may be a useful screening tool for clinicians to implement within the NF1 setting.

details: Internal reliability was good with Person-Separation Index (PSI) = 0.84

details: Cronbach's α coefficients were 0.90 at both time points

_publicationTitle: The development of the PlexiQoL: A patient-reported outcome measure for adults with neurofibromatosis type 1-associated plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Test-retest reliability was 0.90, demonstrating excellent reproducibility

details: Used to identify 7 participants who did not respond logically and 24 participants with extreme scores for exclusion from analysis

_publicationTitle: Phase II trial of pirfenidone in children and young adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 and progressive plexiform neurofibromas.
resourceName: NCI Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) version 3
details: Most frequent pirfenidone related toxicities were nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea; only three patients required dose reduction for toxicities including recurrent grade 2 neutropenia, grade 3 nausea, and grade 3 neutropenia
contextSnippet: The most frequent pirfenidone related toxicities were nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea (Table II). Only three patients required a dose reduction for pirfenidone related toxicities consisting of: (1) recurrent grade 2 neutropenia in cycle 39, (2) grade 3 nausea in cycle 1, and (3) grade 3 neutropenia in cycle 1.

_publicationTitle: Phase II trial of pirfenidone in children and young adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 and progressive plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Parents rated children's cognitive functioning (59.8) as significantly lower than all other domains; adaptive behavior (68.4) was significantly poorer than medical/physical status (76.3)
contextSnippet: Furthermore, parents rated their children's cognitive functioning (59.8) as significantly lower than all the other three domains (adaptive behavior [68.4], P=0.0092; emotional functioning [71.4], P=0.0237; medical/ physical status [76.3], P=0.0002).

_publicationTitle: Phase II trial of pirfenidone in children and young adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 and progressive plexiform neurofibromas.
details: No significant differences found in mean total scores from baseline to pre-cycle 4, 7, or 10 follow-up evaluations as rated by either parents or children (all Ps>0.05)
contextSnippet: No significant differences were found in the mean total scores from baseline to either the pre-cycle 4, 7, or 10 follow-up evaluations as rated by either the parents or children (all Ps>0.05).

_publicationTitle: Phase II trial of pirfenidone in children and young adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 and progressive plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Children's scores were significantly lower than parents' ratings on emotional functioning (63.7 vs. 72.4; P=0.0186) and medical/physical status (67.1 vs. 77.6; P=0.0032)
contextSnippet: In contrast, the children's scores were significantly lower than the parents' ratings on the domains of emotional functioning (63.7 vs. 72.4; F=6.56, P=0.0186) and medical/physical status (67.1 vs. 77.6; F=11.23, P=0.0032).

_publicationTitle: Phase II trial of pirfenidone in children and young adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 and progressive plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Progressive disease by volumetric analysis occurred in 31 patients; median time to progression was 13.2 months; no partial responses were observed
contextSnippet: Reasons for removal from treatment with pirfenidone were: Progressive disease by volumetric analysis (n = 31)... The median TTP on treatment with pirfenidone was 13.2 months... No partial responses were observed.

_publicationTitle: Phase II trial of pirfenidone in children and young adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 and progressive plexiform neurofibromas.
details: In 11 patients with any degree of PN volume decrease, the median % decrease was −4% (range −1 to −12%)
